page.lettertext:
fol.177r
[Apri]
ll
[To M
r
]
Bodly
S
r
. At this present I have not leisure to write so much
as I have cawse towchinge the subject of my letter, but briefuelie
th i s it is: yesterdaie
Mons
r
de Charon
, was w
th
hir
Ma
ty
at my
Sonnes
howse at
Wimbleton,
wheare he delivered unto hir a l
re
from the
Generall States
dated at the Haghe the xj
th
of this moneth
by w
ch
theie gave her Ma
tie
to understand that he had made mon-
[stodane] to the Baron of Reicht, the copie wheareof put into Frenche
the sent jointlie w
th
the same letters unto hir Ma
tie
, of w
ch
awnswere
I dowbt not but yowe have been there made acquainted by the
Counsell
of Estate
, w
ch
hir Ma
tie
hath perused and liketh vearie well, & so
by hir spetiall l
re
s theare dated to the states g
na
ll she hath
largelie signified, and therew
th
hath taken occasion partlie,
uppon their owne writinge, and partlie uppon hir owne Judgement
she hath advised and tould them vearie ernestlie uppon this late
evill succes of the
Frenche K.
whearof I dowbt not but yowe
shall have knowledge over soone, to request them to geve a newe
aide w
th
sum speed to the K. of the like nomber that
Conte
Philip
hath, whome by their owne l
re
theie write theie have
directed to tarrie theme w
th
his forces to the
s
vice of the King,
w
ch
as
their
it
seemed theie judged necessarie, before this evill succes
at
Roan
: so nowe for the recoverie of the K. better fortune hir
Ma
tie
thinketh theie maie be induced to assent to this hir request,
wheareof hir plesure is yo
w
showld take knowledge, and use the
best meanes yowe can to further the same: And bicawse as yowe
knowe the
Conte Maurice
maie be a hinderer theareof, hir
Ma
tie
hath written a verie ernest l
re
privatlie to him: & the
more to spurre him forward hir Ma
tie
hath w
th
hir owne hand
written sum fewe lines in the bottome of his l
re
in sum sort to
taxe him, if he showld not have more regard herein to the
publicque, then to his owne privat honno
r
or glorie, w
ch
word
I will send to yowe by the next, having them not nowe readie
after the sealing of the l
re
, but yowe maie doe well to cause sum
of yo
r
frendes to herken howe he doth accept that postscript & to adv
r
tise
us./
From Westm
r
this xvij
th
of Aprill.
1592
.
Yo
r
verie Loving frend./ William Burghley
I praie you S
r
, move
S
r
Francis Veere
to be a furtherer
of this matter for the Quene./.
